reviewText: "The Bible's Buried Secrets", is an informative and interesting documentary. Many experts on the matter are interviewed and give their opinion's backed and based on archaeological findings. I recommend this video to all truth seekers and believers in the bible, very interesting and presentation of facts and history.
summary: Very Interesting presentation, and educational, I highly recommend.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Moving from archaeological site to site in Israel and Egypt, this program presents what modern archaeology has to tell us about the Old Testament, particularly the Book of Exodus, in a remarkably objective manner. People who view the Bible as being the Word of God may be offended by portions of it, but those of a more inquisitive mind are likely to be intrigued. I was particularly impressed by the Israeli archaeologists, a most intelligent and inquisitive group (I am not Jewish) and found the ultimate (tentative) conclusion about the source of the Jews compelling. Another star in NOVA's crown.
summary: The Kind of Program Where Public Television Excels
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have watched many hours of programing exploring the history of the land and peoples of the middle east.  This program, unlike most of them, does not start out with a pre-conceived position and try to prove it. The producers simply look at the evidence found by the archeologists and let them present the conclusions drawn from what they find. It is fortunate for them, and us, that the ancient Egyptians wrote their history in stone.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Somewhere between Hollywood and Sunday school lies "The Bible's Buried Secrets." Neither an attempt to prove nor disprove the holy scriptures, it aims rather to triangulate by searching the historical and archeological record for independent evidence that could verify the most famous episodes of the Old Testament. Perhaps most illuminating is the theory of the real story behind the Exodus (and especially intriguing for fans like myself of Cecil B. DeMille's epic 1956 version of "The Ten Commandments"). In short, highly recommended for believers and nonbelievers alike.
Title: N/A

reviewText: One of the reviews above says PBS does a good job of staying down the middle, but I would disagree. This documentary actually states that some of the Bible stories are probably myths. They try to back up this statement by saying there is no archeological evidence to support most of these stories. I would say that is a pretty strong statement to try and disprove the Bible. They use the lack of evidence for the Exodus as an example, but this is so far from the truth. Especially since there is strong archeological evidence to support the Exodus. If you want to check out any of those videos, search for these two films.1) The Exodus Revealed2) The Search for the Real Mount Sinai

reviewText: The Nova PBS 2-hour documentary is a comprehensive, educational and archeological guide to how, when and where the Hebrew Bible was composed.  It is interesting to know more about the "good book" and history.  Is it God's will or man's will?  The faith of Abraham created Judaism, Christianity and Islam in the Holy Land and the love your neighbors as yourself tradition does not have peace.  However, a group of Jews came to Kaifeng, China and settled peacefully without being persecuted.  They willingly joined the Chinese family with the family name changed to Chinese, with inter-racial marriage.The Bible had been the beacon of western tradition.  It is wonderful to learn of the background, history and truth supported by scientific and archeological finds.The Lord bless thee, and keep thou:The Lord make his face shine upon thee, and be gracious unto thee:The Lord lift up his countenance upon thee, and give thee peace.  Numbers6: 24-26Mandarins, Jews, And Missionaries: Jewish Experience In The Chinese EmpireJews in Old China: Studies by Chinese Scholars

reviewText: It is amazing that a program like NOVA would admit that the discoveries on the ground are tending to support the age old Biblical story.  Good tape, i recommend it.
summary: NOVA does a pretty good job exploring the Archaeological support for the Biblical story
